These two equations have a single family of characteristics, which consists of parallels to the  $x$  -axis.We shall say that one of these functions,  ${\boldsymbol u}({\boldsymbol x},{\boldsymbol y})$  or  $v(x,y)$  ,is regular in a domain  $D$  ifit is continuous and has continuous first partial derivatives in this domain.It will even be sufficient to say that the derivative with respect to  $y$  is continuous;for if  $\partial u/\partial y$  for example,isa continuous function,equation(l)proves that the same is true of  $\hat{\sigma}^{2}u/\hat{\sigma}x^{2}$  and, consequently,of  $\hat{c}u/\hat{c}x$  
Since equation (l) has constant coefficients,itpossesses particular integralsofthe form  $e^{a x\,+\,b y}$  (IlI,27);the relation between  $a$  and  $^{b}$  is,in this case,  $b=a^{2}.^{2}$  From the integral  $_{e}a x+a^{\frac{3}{2}}y$  thus obtained we can derive any infinity of others by taking its suc- cessive derivatives with respect to theparameter  $^a$  ,or,whatamounts to the same thing,by taking the successive coeffcients of the expansion of this integral,inpowers of  $a$  Letuswritethis expansion in the form 

$$
e^{\alpha x+a^{2}y}=1\,+\sum_{n=1}^{+\infty}\frac{n^{n}}{n!}\,V_{n}(x,\,y)\,;
$$
 
 $V_{n}(x,y)$  isapolynomial of degree  $n$  in  $x,y$  homogeneousin  $\scriptstyle{\mathcal{X}}$  and  $\sqrt{y}$  

$$
\left\{{{\cal V}}_{n}(x,y)\,=\,x^{n}\,+\,n(n\,-\,1)\,x^{n-2}y\,+\,.\,.\,.\right.
$$
 
which is terminated by a term in  $y^{\frac{1}{n}n}$  if  $n$  iseven andbya term in  $x y^{\frac{1}{4}(n-1)}$  ,if  $\pi$  isodd.Thesepolynomials  $V_{n}$  are integrals of equation (1),from their very definition.Wecan easilyverify thisbyobserving that equation(3),differentiated with respect to  $x$  andto  $\mathcal{Y}$  gives the relations

\frac{\partial\,V_{n}}{\partial x}\,=\,n\,V_{n-1},\qquad\frac{\partial\,V_{n}}{\partial y}\,=\,n(n\,-\,1)\,\,V_{n-2},
